section.title: Classes of Citizens
section.para: Before we go further into the user registration process it is worth reviewing the various types of CodeX citizens. There are basically 4 of them:

listitem.para: Anonymous Users: when you first visit the CodeX site you are typically an anonymous user. Anonymous users can browse the CodeX site but many of the CodeX services or CodeX resources cannot be used or accessed by an anonymous user (e.g. source code access is not possible, all the monitoring facilities aren't either, etc.). So we strongly advise you to become a registered user to take full advantage of the CodeX site.

Registered Users: once you have created your own account (see below) you can use your login/password to authenticate yourself with CodeX. Registered users have access to all CodeX projects including source code unless the project administrators decided otherwise. And since the system knows about you, it enables you to customize your view of the system through your Personal Page, monitor Forums, software release, receive support request follow-ups, site updates and many other useful things.

Project Members: users who are actively working on a CodeX hosted project. To become a project member, you must first become a registered user and then ask a project administrator to include you in the project members. Most of the time project members are part of the project team but are not limited to software developers. They can be in charge of the support activity, the project documentation or the project management. Project members can be granted different rights by the Project Administrator according to their role in the team (see for more details).

Project Administrators: registered users who create a new CodeX project are elected as the first Project Administrators. Project Administrators have full rights over their projects except project deletion - a very unusual operation - that can only be done by a CodeX Team member. In the course of the project life, the initial project administrator can grant (or revoke) the status of project administrator to any project member.

Restricted Users: users who are project members, or even project administrators, but with restricted access rights: they cannot access pages from projects they are not member of. This special role is only enabled on CodeX servers in heterogeneous environments where corporate users and external consultants share the same server.

section.title: User Registration
section.para: As suggested above, the first thing to do for a newcomer is to create her own account on CodeX. Becoming a registered CodeX user doesn't imply any commitment on your part to host any of your software projects on CodeX. It simply gives you more freedom when you browse the site and allows CodeX to serve you with personalized information.
Registering on CodeX is quick and easy:

step.para: Give the following information (all items marked with an asterisk are mandatory):
Login Name: your user name. On some CodeX systems that are connected to an enterprise directory you may have to use a pre-defined user name.
Password: 6 characters minimum and repeat it twice to make sure you didn't make any typo in the first occurrence
Full Real Name: what's your name again?

E-mail Address: depending on the site configuration valid email addresses may be limited to those in the &SYS_ORG_NAME; domain (or &SYS_ORG_NAME; affiliated domains). Make sure your email address is corrent or you won't receive the registration confirmation message in your mailbox and won't be able to complete the registration process.

Time Zone: choose the time zone you live in. Choosing the correct time zone is really important. Behind the scene CodeX stores all time stamps in GMT time. Choosing the right time zone allow s CodeX to translate all time stamps to your local time on the Web pages.

Site Updates: check this box if you want to receive site updates from the CodeX Team. This is a low traffic distribution list and we strongly advise you to check this box (default). You'll receive e-mail from us about the site maintenance, the important event in the life of the site, CodeX presentation/training announcement and the CodeX newsletter.

Additional Community Mailings: check this box if you want to receive notification about less important events. You can safely check this box as well if you want because we seldom use it. So we assure you that you won't be overwhelmed with tons of e-mail.

Shortly after you validate the registration form you will receive a message in your mailbox which includes a URL. Clicking on this URL will bring you to a CodeX form asking for your login/password again. If they match then your account is validated and you are now logged into the CodeX site.

tip.title: Tip: CodeX servers with LDAP authentication
tip.para: Your CodeX server might be set up to use an external LDAP directory for authentication. In this case, the registration phase is even simpler: simply type your LDAP login and password, and the system will automatically extract most of the required information from the LDAP directory: email address, real name, etc.

section.para: This 2-step registration process has been put in place for security reasons. Assuming people create their account with an alien e-mail address while they have access to the Intranet, they won't be able to validate their account from the outside because the CodeX machine is behind the firewall. Therefore, an account cannot be validated from outside.

tip.title: Tip: What if I loose my password or my login name?
tip.para: Don't Panic and, above all, do not create a new account! Go to the CodeX Login Page and click on the [Lost your password?] link. You'll be asked your login name and from that CodeX will send you an e-mail message with an embedded URL. Click on this URL and give your new password.

And what if I loose both my login and password? Gee! In this case use the search box and, assuming that you gave your full real name when you first registered, search for your last name and see if you can find your login again in the list of selected users. If so, apply the previous procedure. If not then contact us!

section.title: Login and Personal Page
section.para: To log into the CodeX site, go to the CodeX Site at http://&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN; and click on the "Login" link. If you typed your login and password OK, CodeX presents you with your Personal Page (). At any point in time you can return to your CodeX Personal Page by selecting the "My Personal Page" in the upper part of the CodeX Main Menu.

Your Personal Page is a crossroad from which you can quickly go to CodeX workplaces and information spaces. You'll see bugs and tasks assigned to you in the various projects you belong to. In addition the bug section also shows those bugs that you have submitted including to foreign projects. By doing so, CodeX allows you to follow the evolution of bugs that you have reported and you might be impatient to see fixed.

figure.title: The Personal Page of a CodeX user

section.para: Another section is dedicated to the Discussion Forums and the Software packages that you are currently monitoring. To cancel any of the monitored items just click on the trash icon () next to the item label.

There is also a bookmark section. These are bookmarks to your favorite pages in CodeX. Note that in many cases CodeX uses URL with enough embedded information to bookmark sophisticated items like Software Map browsing, typical search in your project Bug or Task database, etc ... Bookmarked items can be edited which means that both the title of the bookmark and its destination URL can be modified. Finally, the list of projects you belong to is listed in the lower right corner. Selecting any if these projects brings you to the corresponding Project Summary page.

section.title: Account Maintenance
section.para: You provided a certain amount of demographic information to CodeX when you first registered on the CodeX site. This and other information can be modified at any time by selecting the "Account Maintenance" item in the Codex Main Menu.
Most of the items on the "Account Maintenance" page will look obvious to you. However, we would like to draw your attention on some of them:

listitem.para: Edit My Skills Profile: a user can make his resume available on CodeX. The intent here is to let people know about you, your technical background and your domain of expertise. Very useful to get to know each other.

Remember my Login/Password: by default your current login session on CodeX is terminated whenever you stop your Web browser. When you restart your browser and visit CodeX you will be asked for your login/password again. By checking this box you ask CodeX to remember about your login/password forever or at least until you explicitly select the "Logout" item in the CodeX Main Menu. For security reasons we do not recommend using this feature unless you are equipped with a strictly personal desktop machine

CSV separator: CodeX provides you export and import functionalities (See for details). The import/export format is CSV format. Like CSV norm is not implemented by the same way in each software, we allow you to change the CSV separator, in order to fit with your prefered software! The available separators are:
comma (,) : the default separator.
semicolon (;) : used by default by the french version of Excel.
tab (tab).

SSH shared keys: this one has to do with the Shell Account service. When you are a registered user, the CodeX server gives you a personal shell account with the same login/password as for the Web interface.
